pull.title: Enable HW-accelerated implementations of SHA256 for MSVC builds
pull.body:
This PR enables AVX2, SSE4.1 and x86 SHA-NI implementations of SHA256 instead of the "standard" one.

**NOTE about testing**. During runtime the SHA-NI implementation is available only if a CPU has the `sha_ni` flag set.

events.body: Concept ACK—but it does makes me wonder why AVX2 specifically? Would, say, enabling SHANI (which is better on hw that supports it) give a lot of extra work?

> Concept ACK—but it does makes me wonder why AVX2 specifically? Would, say, enabling SHANI (which is better on hw that supports it) give a lot of extra work?

I have no hardware that supports SHANI (

> I have no hardware that supports SHANI (

That's a valid reason. I guess the base work in this PR will make it easier for people who care, to add support the other instruction sets too?

> > I have no hardware that supports SHANI (
> 
> That's a valid reason. I guess the base work in this PR will make it easier for people who care, to add support the other instruction sets too?

Exactly.

### Conflicts

tACK 70f36d816e823d300361f872923f2c3a5f90d476.

*I'm not qualified to verify the safety of changing crypto logic.

I performed an msvc build and then ran the benchmark with and without this PR and there doesn't seem to be much of a difference for `SHA256` on my Intel i7 CPU based PC. I'm not sure if that as expected or not?

On `master`:
````
|             ns/byte |              byte/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|               12.70 |       78,766,206.15 |    2.6% |      0.14 | `SHA1`
|               16.99 |       58,841,181.77 |    1.2% |      0.19 | `SHA256`
|               46.23 |       21,630,470.66 |   11.5% |      0.04 | :wavy_dash: `SHA256D64_1024` (Unstable with ~1.0 iters. Increase `minEpochIterations` to e.g. 10)
|               36.54 |       27,365,792.76 |    1.8% |      0.01 | `SHA256_32b`
|               24.93 |       40,108,453.26 |    3.8% |      0.29 | `SHA3_256_1M`
|               11.64 |       85,924,678.43 |    1.7% |      0.13 | `SHA512`
````

With #24773:
````
|             ns/byte |              byte/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|               13.79 |       72,504,223.37 |    4.9% |      0.16 | `SHA1`
|               18.06 |       55,382,638.65 |    4.6% |      0.21 | `SHA256`
|               88.30 |       11,324,888.97 |   13.0% |      0.06 | :wavy_dash: `SHA256D64_1024` (Unstable with ~1.0 iters. Increase `minEpochIterations` to e.g. 10)
|               56.46 |       17,710,386.66 |   18.7% |      0.01 | :wavy_dash: `SHA256_32b` (Unstable with ~618.0 iters. Increase `minEpochIterations` to e.g. 6180)
|               28.18 |       35,489,686.70 |    2.3% |      0.33 | `SHA3_256_1M`
|               12.35 |       80,963,792.99 |    6.3% |      0.14 | :wavy_dash: `SHA512` (Unstable with ~1.0 iters. Increase `minEpochIterations` to e.g.10)
````
Rebased on top of the merged #24772.
Converted to a "draft" until resolving discussion in #24774.
Closing for now, given you've closed the remaining base PR (#24774). Let me know if this is incorrect / should be reopened.

rename.from: [POC] Enable AVX2 implementation of SHA256 for MSVC builds
rename.to: Enable HW-accelerated implementations of SHA256 for MSVC builds

events.body:
> Would, say, enabling SHANI (which is better on hw that supports it) give a lot of extra work?

Implemented.

> Converted to a "draft" until resolving discussion in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/24774.

No longer based on #24774.

Updated b27defef4218b249a2ec5ec0dd033f62add8daf1 -> 674d3e9a405bebd6388632dbc23b733c65c7887c ([pr24773.03](https://github.com/hebasto/bitcoin/commits/pr24773.03) -> [pr24773.04](https://github.com/hebasto/bitcoin/commits/pr24773.04), [diff](https://github.com/hebasto/bitcoin/compare/pr24773.03..pr24773.04)):

- addressed @fanquake's comments
Friendly ping @sipsorcery :)

Concept ACK. Coming to this after kill/shill/merge, sorry for the late re-review.

Would you mind splitting up the inline changes from the rest? Looks good to me, but as it introduces a general abstraction in the crypto code I think it'd be nice not to restrict review to win32 devs for that part.

After that the changes here look pretty uncontroversial to me (modulo actually verifying the cpuid bitwise stuff).

> Would you mind splitting up the inline changes from the rest?

Just to clarify your point, you mean to put all s/`inline __attribute__((always_inline))`/`ALWAYS_INLINE`/ into the "Introduce platform-agnostic `ALWAYS_INLINE` macro" commit?
Sorry, yes, I meant to factor out those changes into a separate PR.

> Sorry, yes, I meant to factor out those changes into a separate PR.

Thanks! Done in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/27575.

> > Sorry, yes, I meant to factor out those changes into a separate PR.
> 
> Thanks! Done in #27575.

Rebased on top of the #27575 and drafted. Please review #27575 first.

I had a chance to make some benchmarks on a Windows laptop equipped with [Intel Core i9-12950HX](https://ark.intel.com/content/www/us/en/ark/products/228439/intel-core-i912950hx-processor-30m-cache-up-to-5-00-ghz.html) with the `sha_ni` flag set.

No significant difference has been observed. ~Going to close this PR.~ But that is curios.

UPD. Well, the reason is that https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/322ec63b01499c1ec52d3912ee382ebd59f2366b/src/bench/bench_bitcoin.cpp#L64

returns "standard" instead of expected " x86_shani(1way,2way)".
Rebased on top of the merged https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/27575 and undrafted.

Drafted again as it seems worth going https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/27598 and https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/27615 first.

> UPD. Well, the reason is that
> 
> https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/322ec63b01499c1ec52d3912ee382ebd59f2366b/src/bench/bench_bitcoin.cpp#L64
>
> returns "standard" instead of expected " x86_shani(1way,2way)".

Fixed in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/27615.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -67,7 +67,7 @@ static inline int64_t GetPerformanceCounter() noexcept
 #endif
 }
 
-#ifdef HAVE_GETCPUID
+#if defined(HAVE_GETCPUID) && !defined(_MSC_VER)
comments.body: If `GetCPUID` is now implemented for MSVC, why is this skipped?
We already have src/attributes.h. Any reason this is another file?

comments.body:
> If `GetCPUID` is now implemented for MSVC

It is implemented in the first commit.

> why is this skipped?

MSVC does not support inline assembly on x64: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/593979494042e77b5271d42b8f6e7b514e0007d8/src/random.cpp#L129-L136

-#ifdef HAVE_GETCPUID

comments.body:
> It is implemented in the first commit.

I'm aware. That's why I said "is now implemented".

+// Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying

comments.body:
I'm so confused.

Was `GetCPUID` not compiling already? If not, what was guarding it?

And I don't understand the comment about MSVC and assembly. It seems to deal with the randomness example ok?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -67,7 +67,7 @@ static inline int64_t GetPerformanceCounter() noexcept
 #endif
 }
 
-#ifdef HAVE_GETCPUID
+#if defined(HAVE_GETCPUID) && !defined(_MSC_VER)
comments.body:
1. This `#if ... #else ... #endif` [block](https://github.com/hebasto/bitcoin/blob/915bdbdf8c87e20426161bbf393d1036659813a2/src/random.cpp#L69-L185) guards two static functions--`GetRdRand` and `GetRdSeed`--which are not implemented for Windows. Not adding `&& !defined(_MSC_VER)` ends with an error:
```
C:\Users\hebasto\bitcoin\src\random.cpp(137,1): fatal  error C1189: #error:  "RdRand is only supported on x86 and x86_64" [C:\Users\hebasto\bitcoin\build_msvc\li
bbitcoin_util\libbitcoin_util.vcxproj]
```

2. > And I don't understand the comment about MSVC and assembly.

Windows implementation for the `GetRdRand` and `GetRdSeed` was not added because "MSVC does not support inline assembly on x64".

3. > Was `GetCPUID` not compiling already?

It was. On Windows, it is used in the `SHA256AutoDetect` and `AddCPUID` functions.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -67,7 +67,7 @@ static inline int64_t GetPerformanceCounter() noexcept
 #endif
 }
 
-#ifdef HAVE_GETCPUID
+#if defined(HAVE_GETCPUID) && !defined(_MSC_VER)
comments.body: Hmm, ok, we are talking around each-other. I'll ask some detailed questions in code and see if we can clear it up.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -23,4 +23,22 @@ void static inline GetCPUID(uint32_t leaf, uint32_t subleaf, uint32_t& a, uint32
 }
 
 #endif // defined(__x86_64__) || defined(__amd64__) || defined(__i386__)
+
+#if defined(_MSC_VER) && defined(_M_X64)
+#define HAVE_GETCPUID
comments.body: How does this not get defined twice? Does MSVC not define `__x86_64__` or `__amd64__` or `__i386__` ?
Why does the existing asm function not work? What is the specific error? Does it not like the inline asm? Or does it just have a problem with the opcode?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -23,4 +23,22 @@ void static inline GetCPUID(uint32_t leaf, uint32_t subleaf, uint32_t& a, uint32
 }
 
 #endif // defined(__x86_64__) || defined(__amd64__) || defined(__i386__)
+
+#if defined(_MSC_VER) && defined(_M_X64)
+#define HAVE_GETCPUID
comments.body:
> Does MSVC not define `__x86_64__` or `__amd64__` or `__i386__` ?

No, it does not. Easy to verify with the following diff:
```diff
--- a/src/compat/cpuid.h
+++ b/src/compat/cpuid.h
@@ -6,6 +6,7 @@
 #define BITCOIN_COMPAT_CPUID_H

 #if defined(__x86_64__) || defined(__amd64__) || defined(__i386__)
+#error
 #define HAVE_GETCPUID

 #include <cpuid.h>

```
Yeah, MSVC does not support inline asm at all. You have to use intrinsics.
